conclusion: To find the power dissipated in the resistor R, we need to consider the forces acting on the conductor rod MN and the power equation.

The image shows two parallel metal rails connected by a resistor R on the left-hand side. A conductor rod MN is placed on the rails and slides to the right under the influence of a horizontal force F. A uniform magnetic field B is directed vertically downward.
The conductor rod MN is sliding uniformly to the right along the rails.
The force F acting on the rod is the resultant of the magnetic force and the frictional force.
The magnetic force is given by F = Bv, where v is the velocity of the rod.
The frictional force is given by F_f = μN, where N is the normal force and μ is the coefficient of kinetic friction.
The normal force N is given by N = mg, where m is the mass of the rod and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The rod is in equilibrium, so the net force F_net is zero.
The net force F_net is the sum of the magnetic force and the frictional force, so F_net = F + F_f = Bv + μN.
The kinetic energy K of the rod is given by K = (1/2)mv^2.
The work done by the magnetic force on the rod is F · v = Bv^2.
The work done by the frictional force on the rod is F_f · v = μmgv.
The total work done on the rod is W = F_net · v = Bv^2 + μmgv.
The power P dissipated in the resistor R is given by P = W/t, where t is the time taken by the rod to move a distance d.
The time taken by the rod to move a distance d is t = d/v.
Substituting t = d/v into P = W/t gives P = (Bv^2 + μmgv)/(d/v) = Bv + μmg.
The power P dissipated in the resistor R is Bv + μmg.
Given that the distance d is not provided, the exact value of the power P cannot be calculated, but the formula P = Bv + μmg gives the general expression.
